questions: Have you ever heard the term 'office wife' or 'office husband'? What does it mean to you?
Why do you think some people develop close 'work spouse' relationships at the office?
Do you think an office spouse can help relieve work stress, or does it sometimes create more tension?
How close do you think is *too close* for an office husband/wife relationship?
Do you think people naturally connect with certain colleagues as 'office spouses,' or is it something they consciously create?
Do you think having an office spouse can blur the lines between professional and personal life? Why or why not?
How do you think someone should handle it if their actual partner feels uncomfortable about their office spouse?
Do you think these types of relationships can impact office dynamics, positively or negatively?
What boundaries do you think are important to maintain in a work-spouse relationship?
How would you feel if your partner had a very close friend at work they called their 'office husband' or 'office wife'?
What does the phrase 'You Only Need One' (YONO) mean to you? How does it differ from the 'You Only Live Once' (YOLO) mindset?
Have you noticed any changes in your spending habits recently due to inflation or other economic factors? What adjustments have you made?
Do you think young people today feel more pressure to save money compared to previous generations? Why or why not?
What are some strategies or habits you use to avoid unnecessary spending in your daily life?
Have you ever kept a household budget or tracked your expenses? If so, how did it affect your financial decisions?
In what areas of your life do you prioritize spending, even while being frugal? Why do you choose to spend in these areas?
How do you balance saving money with enjoying life and treating yourself occasionally?
Do you think societyâ€™s perception of luxury and status symbols is changing among young people? Why or why not?
Have you ever made a significant lifestyle change, like reducing dining out or cutting back on subscriptions, to save money? How did it feel?
What advice would you give someone who wants to adopt a more frugal lifestyle but doesnâ€™t know where to start?
What are some funny or unusual questions people have asked you because of your job or college major? How did you respond?
Have you noticed any quirky habits or behaviors that are common in your profession or among students in your major? How do they stand out?
Are there any stereotypes about your job or major that you find particularly amusing or frustrating? How do you deal with them?
Have you ever been on a date where someone made assumptions about you based on your profession or major? How did that affect the conversation?
Do you think certain professions or majors are seen as more 'attractive' or 'impressive' in dating or social settings? Why do you think that is?
Whatâ€™s the funniest or most ridiculous thing someone has said to you after learning about your job or major?
Are there any romantic clichÃ©s tied to your profession or major, like 'doctors always marry nurses' or 'philosophy majors are hopeless romantics'? Do you think these are true?
If someone wanted to date someone in your profession or major, what advice would you give them about understanding your work life or studies?
Have you ever bonded with someone over shared professional quirks or experiences from your college major? What was that connection like?
If you could swap professions or majors for a day to experience another fieldâ€™s quirks and stereotypes, which one would it be and why?
